after: The identity of the ethnic core of Xiongnu has been a subject of varied hypotheses, because only a few words, mainly titles and personal names, were preserved in the Chinese sources. Proposals by scholars include multi-ethnic,[1] Mongolic,[2] Turkic,[3] Yeniseian,[4][5] Tocharian, Iranian,[6][7] and Uralic.[8][9] The name Xiongnu may be cognate to the name Huns, but the evidence for this is controversial.[5][10]
